questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with severe headache and dizziness after using a faulty gas heater. Blood tests reveal normal arterial PO2 but significantly elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels, indicating impaired oxygen transport. Which of the following types of hypoxia does not stimulate chemoreceptors?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoxic hypoxia

options.label: B
options.text: Anemic hypoxia

options.label: C
options.text: Stagnant hypoxia

options.label: D
options.text: Histotoxic hypoxia

questions.correct_answer: B. Anemic hypoxia
questions.explanation:
Type of Hypoxia

Features

Chemoreceptor stimulation

Hypoxic hypoxia
  • Decreased PO2
  • Dissolved O2 is low

Chemoreceptor stimulated (+)

(Option A)

Anemic hypoxia
  • PO2 normal
  • Dissolved O2 is normal

Chemoreceptor is not stimulated

Stagnant hypoxia
  • Stagnation of flow (Low blood flow) to glomus cells

Chemoreceptor stimulated (++)

(Option C)

Histotoxic hypoxia
  • Tissue unable to extract oxygen

Chemoreceptor stimulated (++) due to impaired tissue oxygen extraction

(Option D)

questions.text: A 35 year old female hiker ascends to 5,000m in 2 days. Within 24 hours, she develops severe headaches, nausea, coordination difficulties, confusion, and occasional hallucinations. On examination, she is ataxic, with a GCS score of 10 and signs of papilledema. What is the next best step in managing this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate descent to a lower altitude and start oxygen therapy.

options.label: B
options.text: Start dexamethasone and monitor for improvement

options.label: C
options.text: Provide hydration, antiemetics, and continue the ascent

options.label: D
options.text: Administer acetazolamide and maintain current altitude for the next 24 hours at least.

questions.correct_answer: A. Immediate descent to a lower altitude and start oxygen therapy.
questions.explanation:
HIGH-ALTITUDE CEREBRAL EDEMA (HACE)

Category

Details

Cause

Capillary leakage leads to brain swelling, often due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

Symptoms

Severe headache, nausea, vomiting, ataxia (lack of coordination), disorientation, confusion, hallucinations, papilledema, and potentially coma due to herniation of the brain through tentorium.

Mechanism
  • Increased capillary pressure is caused by hypoxia-induced local vasodilation of cerebral blood vessels, leading to fluid leakage into brain tissues.
  • Chemical factors like vascular endothelial growth factor and inflammatory cytokines may also increase endothelial permeability.

Onset

Typically within 8-24 hours after rapid ascent to high altitude; symptoms can progress quickly over the next 4-8 days if untreated.

Treatment
  • First Step - Immediate descent to a lower altitude
  • Administration of oxygen
  • High-dose dexamethasone to reduce cerebral edema and inflammation
  • Acetazolamide to promote acclimatization and reduce CSF formation.
  • Portable Hyperbaric Chamber: Symptoms will return when the patient leaves the chamber, but they may improve briefly, allowing the patient to help with evacuation.

questions.text: A 30 year old hiker arrives at a clinic complaining of severe headache, nausea, and fatigue 12 hours after a rapid ascent to 3,500 meters. Physical examination reveals signs of mild confusion. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely underlying mechanism contributing to his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased cerebral blood flow leading to cerebral edema

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased capillary pressure in the brain due to hypoxia

options.label: C
options.text: Increased oxygen levels in the brain causing vasoconstriction

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased blood-brain barrier permeability due to hypoxia

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased cerebral blood flow leading to cerebral edema
questions.explanation:
Acute Mountain Sickness

Symptoms
  • Headache
  • Nausea
  • Fatigue
  • Insomnia
  • Appear hours to days after rapid ascent

Pathophysiology
  • Associated with cerebral edema, caused by increased capillary pressure in the brain due to dilation of blood vessels in response to low oxygen levels.
  • The increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier contributes to fluid leakage into brain tissue.

Treatment
  • Descending to a lower altitude
  • Supplemental oxygen, and
  • Acetazolamide to facilitate acclimatization.
  • In severe cases, corticosteroids may be used to reduce cerebral edema.

questions.text: A 55 year old man who recently relocated to a high-altitude region presents with worsening breathlessness and signs of right-sided heart failure. His examination reveals elevated pulmonary arterial pressure and symptoms of pulmonary edema. Given these findings, which vascular response to hypoxia is most likely responsible for his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Systemic vasoconstriction causing increased blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Pulmonary vasoconstriction leading to elevated pulmonary arterial pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Systemic vasodilation resulting in decreased oxygen delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased pulmonary blood flow due to systemic vasoconstriction

questions.correct_answer: B. Pulmonary vasoconstriction leading to elevated pulmonary arterial pressure

questions.text: Which adaptation is associated with long-term high-altitude exposure and helps to enhance oxygen delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated systemic blood pressure and reduced capillary surface area

options.label: B
options.text: Increased production of erythropoietin and enhanced hemoglobin levels

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased number of red blood cells and lower 2,3-DPG concentration

options.label: D
options.text: Increased pulmonary blood flow and increased oxygen affinity of hemoglobin

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased production of erythropoietin and enhanced hemoglobin levels
questions.explanation:
Changes to Hypoxia

Cardiovascular
  • Pulmonary vasoconstriction
  • Systemic vasodilation
  • Increased Heart Rate, Cardiac Output, Blood Pressure
  • Angiogenesis

RBC
  • Increased Production (EPO, RBC)
  • Increased Hematocrit and Hemoglobin
  • Increased 2,3 - DPG
 

Note: Significant Polycythemia→ increased blood viscosity→ increased workload of heart→ cardiac hypertrophy.

questions.text: What primary physiological change sustains increased ventilation over several days of high-altitude exposure?

options.label: A
options.text: Initial rapid increase in breathing rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Compensatory renal excretion of bicarbonate.

options.label: C
options.text: Decrease in cerebrospinal fluid pH.

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in respiratory rate over time.

questions.correct_answer: B. Compensatory renal excretion of bicarbonate.

questions.text: When a person ascends to high altitudes, their body undergoes several adaptive changes to cope with lower oxygen levels, a process known as acclimatization. Which of the following correctly describes these physiological changes?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased pulmonary ventilation with respiratory acidosis, elevated EPO levels, higher cardiac output, and angiogenesis in skeletal muscles.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased pulmonary ventilation with respiratory alkalosis, increased RBC production, higher cardiac output, and increased mitochondrial content in skeletal muscles.

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased pulmonary ventilation with respiratory acidosis, decreased RBC production, lower cardiac output, and decreased capillary density in skeletal muscles.

options.label: D
options.text: Unchanged pulmonary ventilation, no changes in blood pH, constant RBC production, and unchanged skeletal muscle characteristics.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased pulmonary ventilation with respiratory alkalosis, increased RBC production, higher cardiac output, and increased mitochondrial content in skeletal muscles.
questions.explanation:
Changes during Acclimatization

Respiratory
  • At high altitudes, lower oxygen levels stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, increasing pulmonary ventilation.
  • This leads to enhanced CO2 removal, causing respiratory alkalosis.
  • Kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate to stabilize blood pH, causing a sustained increase in ventilation and supporting prolonged acclimatization.

Hematological
  • At high altitudes, lower PO2 boosts erythropoietin production, increasing red blood cell count.
  • This also raises 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels in red blood cells.
  • Initially, alkalosis shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the left but increased 2,3-DPG shifts it to the right, improving oxygen release to tissues.

Cardiovascular

  • The heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure increase due to the activation of the sympathoadrenal axis by hypoxia.
  • Increased cardiac output leads to an increase in blood flow, and hypoxia causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation, further contributing to increased blood flow and oxygen supply to the tissues.

Tissue
  • In acclimatization, skeletal muscles undergo several changes, including an increase in the number of capillaries and mitochondria and an increase in myoglobin content.
  • Further, chemicals released from the hypoxic tissues stimulate angiogenesis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old climber at 4,500 meters (14,764 feet) develops severe headache, nausea, and breathlessness after 36 hours. Even with supplemental oxygen, his symptoms worsen with confusion and coordination loss, prompting his team to descend.What likely caused his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS).

options.label: B
options.text: High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE).

options.label: C
options.text: High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE).

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in alveolar PCO2.

questions.correct_answer: C. High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE).
questions.explanation:
Condition

Description

Symptoms

Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS)

(Option A)

A common condition, developing within 8-24 hours of ascent, lasting 4-8 days.

Headache, irritability, insomnia, breathlessness, nausea, vomiting.

High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE)

Develops within 1-3 days. Progression of AMS with significant brain swelling due to capillary leakage.

Ataxia, disorientation, potential coma, death.

High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE)

(Option B)

Patchy edema in lungs from increased pulmonary arterial pressure.

Fluid accumulation, and increased capillary pressure- causing cough, dyspnea, and chest pain.

questions.text: On a hike, a healthy 35 year old mountaineer starts feeling severe dizziness, confusion, and shortness of breath at a high altitude (12,000 meters or 39,370 feet) despite using supplemental oxygen. His team measures his alveolar oxygen levels and finds them significantly low. They choose to descend to a lower altitude promptly. What is the likely reason for his symptoms and the team's decision to descend?

options.label: A
options.text: The barometric pressure at 12,000meters is too low to maintain adequate PO2 even with supplemental oxygen.

options.label: B
options.text: The barometric pressure at 12,000 meters causes body fluids to boil.

options.label: C
options.text: The composition of the air changes drastically at high altitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: The mountaineer's alveolar PCO2 increases due to increased ventilation.

questions.correct_answer: A. The barometric pressure at 12,000meters is too low to maintain adequate PO2 even with supplemental oxygen.

questions.text: A 50 year old man is found unconscious after a fire in a closed space. Upon investigation of the scene, it was discovered that there was a cyanide gas attack and the patient is severely hypoxic The doctor suspects that he is suffering from histotoxic hypoxia. Which of the following is NOT seen in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibition of cellular metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: High venous PO2

options.label: C
options.text: Normal arterial PO2

options.label: D
options.text: Cyanosis

questions.correct_answer: D. Cyanosis
questions.explanation:
Type of Hypoxia

Features

Cyanosis

Hypoxic hypoxia

Low O2 saturation in arterial and venous blood

Cyanosis ++

Anemic hypoxia
  1. Anemia
  2. Methemoglobinemia
  • Cyanosis seen rarely
  • Cyanosis-like appearance

Stagnant hypoxia

Reduced O2 saturation in venous blood

Cyanosis ++

Histotoxic hypoxia

O2 saturation is normal in arterial blood and high in venous blood

Cyanosis never seen

questions.text: A 50-year-old man experiences severe shortness of breath and dizziness while climbing a mountain. Which of the following is the most common form of hypoxia?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoxic hypoxia

options.label: B
options.text: Stagnant hypoxia

options.label: C
options.text: Anemic hypoxia

options.label: D
options.text: Histotoxic hypoxia

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypoxic hypoxia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Stagnant hypoxia is where tissues cannot utilize O2 despite a normal supply

options.label: B
options.text: Heart failure causes histotoxic hypoxia

options.label: C
options.text: Stagnant hypoxia is due to the inhibition of tissue oxidative processes

options.label: D
options.text: Artery venous oxygen difference increases in stagnant hypoxia

questions.correct_answer: D. Artery venous oxygen difference increases in stagnant hypoxia
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Stagnant Hypoxia

Histotoxic hypoxia

Definition

Hypoxia due to decreased blood flow to tissues

Hypoxia where tissues cannot utilize O2 despite normal O2 supply (Option A)

Mechanism

Normal arterial O2 content, hypoxia due to stagnation of blood circulation

Inhibition of tissue oxidative processes (Option C).

Conditions associated

  • Heart failure (decreased cardiac output) (Option B)
  • Shock
  • Vascular obstruction (decreased blood flow)
  • Cyanide poisoning- Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase. Tissue oxidation is paralyzed.
  • Severe diphtheria-
    Diphtheria toxin inhibits cytochrome synthesis.

Consequences

Local acidosis from lactate accumulation

Inhibition of cellular metabolism

Treatment

Address underlying cause (e.g., improve cardiac output)

Cyanide poisoning: Methylene blue or nitrites, Hyperbaric O2 therapy

Arterial and Venous blood oxygen

With no adequate blood supply, the tissue will keep extracting more and more oxygen from the same blood leading to a low oxygen level in the venous blood.

The arterial and venous blood oxygen difference will increase.

Tissues cannot extract oxygen from the blood hence level of venous blood oxygen will be higher than normal.

The artery venous oxygen difference will decrease.

questions.text: A diver experiences joint pain, dizziness, and motor weakness after rapidly ascending from a deep dive. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of his symptoms and outlines the immediate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Nitrogen bubbles formed during rapid ascent obstruct small blood vessels; treatment is high-flow oxygen therapy

options.label: B
options.text: High atmospheric pressure increases nitrogen dissolution in tissues; immediate recompression followed by slow decompression is essential.

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen toxicity due to high partial pressures; reducing oxygen concentration and administering IV fluids is required.

options.label: D
options.text: Dehydration from prolonged diving; rehydration and analgesics for joint pain are the primary treatments

questions.correct_answer: B. High atmospheric pressure increases nitrogen dissolution in tissues; immediate recompression followed by slow decompression is essential.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Definition
  • Occurs when subjects exposed to high atmospheric pressures are suddenly brought to low atmospheric pressures
  • Include deep-sea divers or workers in caissons returning to the surface rapidly or rapid ascent in an unpressurized airplane cabin.

Pressure Changes
  • Sea Level: 1 atmosphere.
  • Depth: Pressure increases by 1 atmosphere for every 10 meters
  • Nitrogen at Sea Level: 1 liter dissolved in the body (half in water, half in fat).

Mechanism
  • Nitrogen Dissolution: Divers breathe 80% nitrogen from gas mixtures. Nitrogen dissolves in body fluids and lipid structures of tissues, proportional to the depth of descent.
  • Slow Ascent: Gases diffuse into the blood and are eliminated by the lungs.
  • Rapid Ascent: Rapid escape of gases forms bubbles in tissues and blood, causing damage.

Symptoms
  • Onset: Symptoms usually appear within half an hour of surfacing.
  • Mild: Severe pain in muscles and joints (decompression sickness or caisson disease)-bends
  • Severe:
    • Bubbles decrease blood flow to the brain and spinal cord causing sensory and motor deficits (paresthesia, motor weakness, paralysis, respiratory failure).
    • Bubbles in pulmonary vessels cause dyspnea and respiratory compression.-chokes
    • Bubbles in coronary vessels cause myocardial ischemia

Treatment
  • Immediate recompression in a pressurized cabin followed by slow decompression.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is helpful.
  • Recovery is usually complete, though some residual neural deficits may persist.

Decompression Time

Depth

10 minutes

50ft

17 minutes

40ft

19 minutes

30ft

50 minutes

20ft

84 minutes

10ft

questions.text: A diver at 150 feet depth begins to exhibit signs of drowsiness and impaired coordination, likely experiencing nitrogen narcosis. Which of the following statements is incorrect about nitrogen narcosis at this depth?

options.label: A
options.text: Nitrogen narcosis can cause euphoria at depths around 120 feet.

options.label: B
options.text: Symptoms of nitrogen narcosis worsen progressively with increasing depth.

options.label: C
options.text: The effects of nitrogen narcosis are irreversible even after ascending to a shallower depth.

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrogen narcosis occurs due to nitrogen dissolving in fatty neuronal membranes.

questions.correct_answer: C. The effects of nitrogen narcosis are irreversible even after ascending to a shallower depth.

questions.text: A 40 year old deep-sea diver experiences shortness of breath and dizziness after prolonged use of a rebreathing apparatus. His symptoms worsen despite increased breathing efforts, indicating possible CO2 buildup in his equipment. What is the tolerable level up to which alveolar CO2 pressure (Pco2) can go for a diver?

options.label: A
options.text: 40mm Hg

options.label: B
options.text: 60mm Hg

options.label: C
options.text: 80mm Hg

options.label: D
options.text: 100mm Hg

questions.correct_answer: C. 80mm Hg

questions.text: A 38-year-old diver, after a deep dive with a partial pressure of oxygen of 5 atm for 50 minutes, develops sudden muscle twitching, visual disturbances, and seizures upon surfacing, necessitating urgent medical attention. What is the most likely mechanism responsible for the diver’s symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Excessive production of oxygen-free radicals leading to cellular damage

options.label: B
options.text: Direct damage to lung tissue from high partial pressure of oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: Hypoxia caused by inadequate oxygen supply to the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Barotrauma due to pressure changes affecting air-filled spaces

questions.correct_answer: A. Excessive production of oxygen-free radicals leading to cellular damage
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Acute Oxygen Toxicity

Chronic Oxygen Toxicity

Pressure

Breathing O2 at ≧4 atm

Exposure to 1 atm pressure of O2 for about 12 hours

Symptoms

Seizures, coma, nausea, muscle twitching, dizziness, visual disturbances, irritability, disorientation

Lung congestion, pulmonary edema, atelectasis

Mechanism

Overproduction of oxygen free radicals (superoxide, hydrogen peroxide) overwhelms enzyme systems

Direct exposure of lung tissues to high O2 pressure damages bronchi and alveoli linings

Affected Tissues

Nervous system (high lipid content)

Lungs (direct exposure)

Onset

Symptoms appear within 30 to 60 minutes, often without warning

Develops after prolonged exposure (around 12 hours)

Severity with Exercise

Exercise increases the severity and earlier onset of symptoms

Exercise does not significantly affect the development of symptoms

Treatment

In gas mixtures intended for inhalation at high pressures, the oxygen concentration is reduced to approximately 20% to prevent oxygen toxicity

questions.text: How does the SCUBA demand system ensure that air is supplied to the diver only when needed?

options.label: A
options.text: The air is continuously supplied to the mask at a constant pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: The first-stage reducing valve maintains a constant high pressure on the mask.

options.label: C
options.text: Air is supplied to the mask only during inhalation through a demand valve.

options.label: D
options.text: Exhaled air is redirected back into the tank for reuse.

questions.correct_answer: C. Air is supplied to the mask only during inhalation through a demand valve.
questions.explanation:
Self-contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA)

Aspect

Details

Components

1. Tanks of compressed air or breathing mixture of oxygen and helium

2. First-stage reducing valve (lowers high tank pressure to low pressure)

3. Combination inhalation demand valve and exhalation valve

4. Mask and tube system with small “dead space”

Principle
  • The reducing valve lowers tank pressure to a few mm Hg above surrounding water pressure.
  • Air is delivered to the mask only during inhalation through the demand valve.
  • Exhaled air is expelled into the water, not back into the tank.

Uses
  • Popular in sports and commercial diving (99% of cases).
  • Limited time underwater, e.g., a few minutes at 200 feet depth due to the high airflow needed to remove CO2.

Image

questions.text: A diver descends to a depth of 300 feet in the sea. If the atmospheric pressure at sea level is 760 mmHg (1 atm), what is the total pressure experienced by the diver at this depth?

options.label: A
options.text: 31 atm

options.label: B
options.text: 30 atm

options.label: C
options.text: 11 atm

options.label: D
options.text: 10 atm

questions.correct_answer: D. 10 atm

questions.text: A 45 year old female climber, who reached 5,200m in 36 hours, presents with severe dyspnea, persistent cough with pink, frothy sputum, fatigue, cyanosis, and oxygen saturation of 75% on room air. Despite supplemental oxygen, her condition does not improve. The team is considering interventions. Which treatment option is least effective for severe HAPE in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate descent to a lower altitude and administration of supplemental oxygen.

options.label: B
options.text: Use of a portable hyperbaric chamber and provide high-flow oxygen.

options.label: C
options.text: Providing aggressive hydration and using diuretics to reduce pulmonary edema.

options.label: D
options.text: Starting nifedipine and preparing for emergency evacuation

questions.correct_answer: C. Providing aggressive hydration and using diuretics to reduce pulmonary edema.
questions.explanation:
High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE)

Category

Details

Cause

Marked pulmonary hypertension that develops at high altitude due to severe hypoxia causing uneven vasoconstriction of pulmonary arterioles.

Symptoms
  • Patchy edema of the lungs,
  • Severe pulmonary dysfunction,
  • Cough
  • Dyspnea
  • Chest pain

Mechanism

Severe hypoxia causes powerful constriction of pulmonary arterioles, but the constriction is uneven, leading to increased blood flow and high capillary pressure in unconstricted areas, resulting in capillary wall disruption (stress failure).

Onset

From a few hours to up to 5 days after rapid ascent to high altitude.

Prophylaxis
  • Only started for people with a previous history of HAPE, specifically with recurrence.
  • Gradual Ascent.
  • Extended-release Nifedipine, 30 mg every 12 hours, starting the day before ascent and continuing for 4-7 days after reaching the target elevation or until descent.

Treatment
  • Immediate descent to a lower altitude (Option A)
  • Administration of oxygen
  • Use of a hyperbaric chamber, if available (Option B)
  • Nifedipine (a Ca2+ channel blocker that lowers pulmonary artery pressure) (Option D)
  • Diuretics and Acetazolamide are not recommended for HAPE. (Option C)

questions.text: A 45 year old woman presents with fatigue and dyspnea. Her blood tests reveal a low hemoglobin concentration and despite normal arterial oxygen saturation. Which type of hypoxia is most consistent with patients' findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoxic hypoxia

options.label: B
options.text: Stagnant hypoxia

options.label: C
options.text: Anemic hypoxia

options.label: D
options.text: Histotoxic hypoxia

questions.correct_answer: C. Anemic hypoxia
